item.title: Krappy Korners: simply the worst of San Francisco
item.trailText: Dumped watermelon carcasses, decapitated logs and stairways to nowhere ... Arthur Tress has spent years wandering the City by the Bay finding the most amusingly awful scenes to photograph. Here are the krappiest spots so far

cards.title: 'Like something out of Jurassic Park' / Bringing an extinct frog back from the dead
cards.rawTitle: Bringing an extinct frog back from the dead

item.title: The gastric-brooding frog: how to bring a species back from the dead
item.trailText: The remarkable story of how the gastric-brooding frog is being brought back from extinction by scientists
item.standFirst:
Australia's gastric-brooding frog was discovered in the 1970s but by the early 1980s was classed as extinct. However, this remarkable frog, which projectile-vomits its young after gestating them in its stomach, is the subject of ground-breaking research at the University of New South Wales to recreate an extinct species.

This is the second in a series from UNSW, Catastrophic Science, on natural disasters

cards.title: Are Londoners too rude and busy to care?
cards.rawTitle: Are Londoners too rude and busy to care?

item.title: Are Londoners too rude and busy to care?
item.trailText: Hidden cameras reveal how Londoners react to strangers in need
item.standFirst: Would you stop to pick up spilt groceries or help with a heavy bag? What if a man asked to be woken at his tube stop? Find out how busy Londoners respond to small opportunities for kindness – and enjoy the unexpected rewards for those willing to help a stranger in need

cards.title: Tottenham Hotspur to host NFL games at new stadium
cards.rawTitle: Tottenham Hotspur to host NFL games at new stadium

item.title: Tottenham Hotspur to host NFL games at new stadium
item.trailText: Tottenham Hotspur announce on Wednesday that they have agreed to a 10-year deal with the NFL to stage at least two games a year
item.standFirst: Tottenham Hotspur announce on Wednesday that they have agreed to a 10-year deal with the NFL to stage at least two games a year. The new stadium, which will hold 61,000 spectators, will have an artificial surface for NFL games installed under the regular grass pitch which will be used by Spurs

cards.title: Tristram Kenton / Star snapper of the stage

item.title: Tristram Kenton: star snapper of the stage
item.trailText: Tristram Kenton’s photographs have accompanied arts reviews and features in the Guardian for more than 20 years. As an exhibition of his work goes on display, he introduces a selection of his images
item.standFirst:
Tristram Kenton’s photographs have accompanied arts reviews and features in the Guardian for more than 20 years. As an exhibition of his work goes on display at the Guardian’s Kings Place office, he introduces a selection of images capturing some of the world’s most talented performers

Michael Billington: In recording the art of theatre, Tristram Kenton creates another with his camera

displayImages.caption:
Daniel Day-Lewis as Hamlet at the National Theatre, London, 1989
‘Half in the shadows, this photograph was taken during Daniel Day-Lewis’s last stage production. He left Hamlet mid-performance and said that he’d seen the ghost of his father.’

All photographs: Tristram Kenton
displayImages.altText: Daniel Day-Lewis as Hamlet at the National Theatre, March 1989
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Daniel Day-Lewis as Hamlet at the National Theatre, London, 1989
‘Half in the shadows, this photograph was taken during Daniel Day-Lewis’s last stage production. He left Hamlet mid-performance and said that he’d seen the ghost of his father.’

All photographs: Tristram Kenton

displayImages.caption:
Mark Rylance in Jerusalem at the Apollo in London, 2010
‘Mark Rylance doesn’t just act, he lives his roles. In Jerusalem, he nightly downed a raw egg, chopped wood, was beaten up and had his head dunked in water. An award-winning physical performance, mesmerising to watch.’
displayImages.altText: Mark Rylance in Jerusalem at the Apollo in London, 2010
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Mark Rylance in Jerusalem at the Apollo in London, 2010
‘Mark Rylance doesn’t just act, he lives his roles. In Jerusalem, he nightly downed a raw egg, chopped wood, was beaten up and had his head dunked in water. An award-winning physical performance, mesmerising to watch.’

displayImages.caption:
More or Less Infinity by Compagnie 111 at Queen Elizabeth Hall, London, 2006
‘The strobe in this production allowed me to choose a slow shutter speed, blurring part of the image but freezing movement too.’
displayImages.altText: More Or Less Infinity by Compagnie 111, 2006
displayImages.cleanCaption:
More or Less Infinity by Compagnie 111 at Queen Elizabeth Hall, London, 2006
‘The strobe in this production allowed me to choose a slow shutter speed, blurring part of the image but freezing movement too.’

displayImages.caption:
in-i at the National Theatre, London, 2008
‘Juliet Binoche’s first dance project, a collaboration with Akram Khan. I like the composition and colour.’
displayImages.altText: in-i at the National Theatre, 2008 with Juliette Binoche
displayImages.cleanCaption:
in-i at the National Theatre, London, 2008
‘Juliet Binoche’s first dance project, a collaboration with Akram Khan. I like the composition and colour.’

displayImages.caption:
Maggie Smith in The Importance of Being Earnest at the Aldwych theatre, London, 1993
‘Classic Maggie Smith. Lady Bracknell was a perfect part for her wonderful voice.’
displayImages.altText: Maggie Smith in the Importance Of Being Earnest at the Aldwych theatre, 1993
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Maggie Smith in The Importance of Being Earnest at the Aldwych theatre, London, 1993
‘Classic Maggie Smith. Lady Bracknell was a perfect part for her wonderful voice.’

displayImages.caption:
Carlos Acosta in Diana and Actaeon at the London London Coliseum, 2008
‘One of the greatest ballet dancers in the world in full flight.’
displayImages.altText: Carlos Acosta in Diana and Actaeon at the London Coliseum, 2008
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Carlos Acosta in Diana and Actaeon at the London London Coliseum, 2008
‘One of the greatest ballet dancers in the world in full flight.’

displayImages.caption:
Michael Feast and Samuel West in Doctor Faustus at Minerva Theatre, Chichester, 2004
‘It’s an arresting photo. Makes you wonder what’s going on…’
displayImages.altText: Michael Feast and Samuel West in Doctor Faustus at Minerva Theatre, Chichester
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Michael Feast and Samuel West in Doctor Faustus at Minerva Theatre, Chichester, 2004
‘It’s an arresting photo. Makes you wonder what’s going on…’

displayImages.caption:
Nicole Kidman in The Blue Room at the Donmar, London, 1998
‘This was the moment that Hollywood came to the West End. I chose this image for the strong colour and for showing Nicole Kidman taking risks.’
displayImages.altText: Nicole Kidman in The Blue Room at the Donmar, 1998
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Nicole Kidman in The Blue Room at the Donmar, London, 1998
‘This was the moment that Hollywood came to the West End. I chose this image for the strong colour and for showing Nicole Kidman taking risks.’

displayImages.caption:
Schmetterling by Nederlands Dans Theater at Sadler’s Wells, London, 2014
‘I like the extreme expressions on the faces of the dancers. It’s important to create a visual impact on the Guardian review pages.’
displayImages.altText: Schmetterling by Nederlands Dans Theater at Sadler’s Wells, 2014
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Schmetterling by Nederlands Dans Theater at Sadler’s Wells, London, 2014
‘I like the extreme expressions on the faces of the dancers. It’s important to create a visual impact on the Guardian review pages.’

displayImages.caption:
Judi Dench and Oliver Chris in A Midsummer Night’s Dream at the Rose theatre, Kingston, 2010
‘This shows Judi Dench giving everything in performance – and this was just a photocall!’
displayImages.altText: Judi Dench in A Midsummer Night’s Dream at the Rose Theatre, Kingston, 2010
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Judi Dench and Oliver Chris in A Midsummer Night’s Dream at the Rose theatre, Kingston, 2010

Pavlo Hunka in Le Grand Macabre at London Coliseum, 2009
‘This picture captures the reason why the English National Opera have built up a strong reputation for staging opera in controversial and inventive ways.’

Julie Anne Stanzak, centre, in Tanztheater Wuppertal’s Nelken at Sadler’s Wells, London, 2005
‘I love Pina Bausch’s work. At the same time shocking, disturbing, visually stunning, with a comment on humanity.’

Lenny Henry as Othello at the West Yorkshire Playhouse, 2009
‘Lenny Henry has made the successful transformation from comedian to serious actor. This photo shows his charisma.’
displayImages.altText: Lenny Henry as Othello at the West Yorkshire Playhouse, 2009
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Lenny Henry as Othello at the West Yorkshire Playhouse, 2009
‘Lenny Henry has made the successful transformation from comedian to serious actor. This photo shows his charisma.’

displayImages.caption:
Cornell S John in Porgy and Bess at the Savoy, London, 2006
‘In Trevor Nunn’s production I wanted to capture a drunken Cornell S John with the world spinning around, out of his control.’
displayImages.altText: A scene from Porgy & Bess at the Savoy
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Cornell S John in Porgy and Bess at the Savoy, London, 2006
‘In Trevor Nunn’s production I wanted to capture a drunken Cornell S John with the world spinning around, out of his control.’

displayImages.caption:
Patrick Stewart as Claudius and David Tennant as Hamlet at the Novello theatre, London, 2008
‘Capturing Hamlet’s madness and David Tennant’s great acting.’
displayImages.altText: Patrick Stewart as Claudius and David Tennant as Hamlet, 2008
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Patrick Stewart as Claudius and David Tennant as Hamlet at the Novello theatre, London, 2008
‘Capturing Hamlet’s madness and David Tennant’s great acting.’

displayImages.caption:
Peter O’Toole in Jeffrey Bernard Is Unwell at the Apollo theatre, London, 1989
‘I’m lucky to have seen Peter O’Toole give this performance. He seemed very good at acting drunk…’
displayImages.altText: Peter O'Toole in Jeffrey Bernard Is Unwell at the Apollo theatre, London, 1989.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Peter O’Toole in Jeffrey Bernard Is Unwell at the Apollo theatre, London, 1989
‘I’m lucky to have seen Peter O’Toole give this performance. He seemed very good at acting drunk…’

displayImages.caption:
Here Lies Love at the Dorfman theatre, London, 2014
‘I like the colours, detail and expressions in this picture of David Byrne and Fatboy Slim’s musical about Imelda Marcos.’
displayImages.altText: Imelda Marcos in Here Lies Love by David Byrne and Fatboy Slim, 2014
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Here Lies Love at the Dorfman theatre, London, 2014
‘I like the colours, detail and expressions in this picture of David Byrne and Fatboy Slim’s musical about Imelda Marcos.’

displayImages.caption:
Pete Postlethwaite as King Lear at the Young Vic, London, in 2009
‘Life’s experience chiselled into his face. This is the Pete Postlethwaite we all loved.’ Photograph: Tristram Kenton for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Pete Postlethwaite as King Lear at the Young Vic in 2009
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Pete Postlethwaite as King Lear at the Young Vic, London, in 2009
‘Life’s experience chiselled into his face. This is the Pete Postlethwaite we all loved.’
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tristram Kenton for the Guardian

displayImages.caption:
Limen at the Royal Opera House, London, 2011
‘Sarah Lamb and Eric Underwood look great together. I like the shape of this picture.’
displayImages.altText: Limen by The Royal Ballet , 2011
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Limen at the Royal Opera House, London, 2011
‘Sarah Lamb and Eric Underwood look great together. I like the shape of this picture.’

displayImages.caption:
Sarah Lamb in Swan Lake at the Royal Opera House, London, 2011
‘A moment when Sarah Lamb stands still on stage with the corps de ballet dancing around her. A slow shutter speed of 1/30 second isolates her.’

Tristram Kenton: Photographs is on display at Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU, until 2 August 2015.
displayImages.altText: Sarah Lamb in Swan Lake at the Royal Opera House, 2011
displayImages.cleanCaption:

image.caption:
Daniel Day-Lewis as Hamlet at the National Theatre, London, 1989
‘Half in the shadows, this photograph was taken during Daniel Day-Lewis’s last stage production. He left Hamlet mid-performance and said that he’d seen the ghost of his father.’

All photographs: Tristram Kenton
image.altText: Daniel Day-Lewis as Hamlet at the National Theatre, March 1989
image.cleanCaption:
Daniel Day-Lewis as Hamlet at the National Theatre, London, 1989
‘Half in the shadows, this photograph was taken during Daniel Day-Lewis’s last stage production. He left Hamlet mid-performance and said that he’d seen the ghost of his father.’

All photographs: Tristram Kenton

image.caption:
Mark Rylance in Jerusalem at the Apollo in London, 2010
‘Mark Rylance doesn’t just act, he lives his roles. In Jerusalem, he nightly downed a raw egg, chopped wood, was beaten up and had his head dunked in water. An award-winning physical performance, mesmerising to watch.’
image.altText: Mark Rylance in Jerusalem at the Apollo in London, 2010
image.cleanCaption:
Mark Rylance in Jerusalem at the Apollo in London, 2010
‘Mark Rylance doesn’t just act, he lives his roles. In Jerusalem, he nightly downed a raw egg, chopped wood, was beaten up and had his head dunked in water. An award-winning physical performance, mesmerising to watch.’

image.caption:
More or Less Infinity by Compagnie 111 at Queen Elizabeth Hall, London, 2006
‘The strobe in this production allowed me to choose a slow shutter speed, blurring part of the image but freezing movement too.’
image.altText: More Or Less Infinity by Compagnie 111, 2006
image.cleanCaption:
More or Less Infinity by Compagnie 111 at Queen Elizabeth Hall, London, 2006
‘The strobe in this production allowed me to choose a slow shutter speed, blurring part of the image but freezing movement too.’

image.caption:
in-i at the National Theatre, London, 2008
‘Juliet Binoche’s first dance project, a collaboration with Akram Khan. I like the composition and colour.’
image.altText: in-i at the National Theatre, 2008 with Juliette Binoche
image.cleanCaption:
in-i at the National Theatre, London, 2008
‘Juliet Binoche’s first dance project, a collaboration with Akram Khan. I like the composition and colour.’

image.caption:
Maggie Smith in The Importance of Being Earnest at the Aldwych theatre, London, 1993
‘Classic Maggie Smith. Lady Bracknell was a perfect part for her wonderful voice.’
image.altText: Maggie Smith in the Importance Of Being Earnest at the Aldwych theatre, 1993
image.cleanCaption:
Maggie Smith in The Importance of Being Earnest at the Aldwych theatre, London, 1993
‘Classic Maggie Smith. Lady Bracknell was a perfect part for her wonderful voice.’

image.caption:
Carlos Acosta in Diana and Actaeon at the London London Coliseum, 2008
‘One of the greatest ballet dancers in the world in full flight.’
image.altText: Carlos Acosta in Diana and Actaeon at the London Coliseum, 2008
image.cleanCaption:
Carlos Acosta in Diana and Actaeon at the London London Coliseum, 2008
‘One of the greatest ballet dancers in the world in full flight.’

image.caption:
Michael Feast and Samuel West in Doctor Faustus at Minerva Theatre, Chichester, 2004
‘It’s an arresting photo. Makes you wonder what’s going on…’
image.altText: Michael Feast and Samuel West in Doctor Faustus at Minerva Theatre, Chichester
image.cleanCaption:
Michael Feast and Samuel West in Doctor Faustus at Minerva Theatre, Chichester, 2004
‘It’s an arresting photo. Makes you wonder what’s going on…’

image.caption:
Nicole Kidman in The Blue Room at the Donmar, London, 1998
‘This was the moment that Hollywood came to the West End. I chose this image for the strong colour and for showing Nicole Kidman taking risks.’
image.altText: Nicole Kidman in The Blue Room at the Donmar, 1998
image.cleanCaption:
Nicole Kidman in The Blue Room at the Donmar, London, 1998
‘This was the moment that Hollywood came to the West End. I chose this image for the strong colour and for showing Nicole Kidman taking risks.’

image.caption:
Schmetterling by Nederlands Dans Theater at Sadler’s Wells, London, 2014
‘I like the extreme expressions on the faces of the dancers. It’s important to create a visual impact on the Guardian review pages.’
image.altText: Schmetterling by Nederlands Dans Theater at Sadler’s Wells, 2014
image.cleanCaption:
Schmetterling by Nederlands Dans Theater at Sadler’s Wells, London, 2014
‘I like the extreme expressions on the faces of the dancers. It’s important to create a visual impact on the Guardian review pages.’

image.caption:
Judi Dench and Oliver Chris in A Midsummer Night’s Dream at the Rose theatre, Kingston, 2010
‘This shows Judi Dench giving everything in performance – and this was just a photocall!’
image.altText: Judi Dench in A Midsummer Night’s Dream at the Rose Theatre, Kingston, 2010
image.cleanCaption:
Judi Dench and Oliver Chris in A Midsummer Night’s Dream at the Rose theatre, Kingston, 2010
‘This shows Judi Dench giving everything in performance – and this was just a photocall!’

image.caption:
Pavlo Hunka in Le Grand Macabre at London Coliseum, 2009
‘This picture captures the reason why the English National Opera have built up a strong reputation for staging opera in controversial and inventive ways.’
image.altText: Pavlo Hunka in Le Grand Macabre at London Coliseum, 2009
image.cleanCaption:
Pavlo Hunka in Le Grand Macabre at London Coliseum, 2009
‘This picture captures the reason why the English National Opera have built up a strong reputation for staging opera in controversial and inventive ways.’

image.caption:
Julie Anne Stanzak, centre, in Tanztheater Wuppertal’s Nelken at Sadler’s Wells, London, 2005
‘I love Pina Bausch’s work. At the same time shocking, disturbing, visually stunning, with a comment on humanity.’
image.altText: Julie Anne Stanzak in Nelken at Sadler’s Wells, 2005
image.cleanCaption:
Julie Anne Stanzak, centre, in Tanztheater Wuppertal’s Nelken at Sadler’s Wells, London, 2005
‘I love Pina Bausch’s work. At the same time shocking, disturbing, visually stunning, with a comment on humanity.’
